data.title: Antero Midstream: Free Cash Flow Nearly Doubles From The Last Fiscal Year Comparison
data.description:
Ever since the oil and gas industry was seen as a far lower growth industry than it was the case over a decade ago, there has been an unparalleled increase in attention paid to free cash flow. Antero Midstream Corporation (AM) just mentioned that free cash flow took a roughly 94% leap over the same quarter in the previous fiscal year. That is the kind of leap that keeps future stock price appreciation as a reasonable goal from the current price.

A lot of LNG export capacity continues to come online. There is also a focus on datacenter growth as another potentially large increase in the use of natural gas. All of this could mean that the North American natural gas market could well join the much stronger world pricing market. Since the stock prices of the midstream industry tend to follow the lead of upstream stock prices, it could well mean that there is more appreciation potential in the future for this stock.

The parent company, Antero Resources (AR), placed a "spot rig" on dry gas acreage that had not been drilled for some time. That is an extremely visible vote for a very favorable commodity price future that many believe the industry faces.

It is possible that capital requirements for Antero Midstream could increase in the future if Antero Resources elects to take advantage of the situation by growing production. If that is the case, the growth of the Midstream Business would mean more free cash flow in the future that could be distributed to shareholders or used in stock repurchases.

It was also mentioned that the company purchased treasury shares during the quarter. This is likewise a potential vote for the opinion that the stock is undervalued.

Earnings And Free Cash Flow After Dividends

Earnings also grew in the teens in the comparison shown below:

Note that the dramatic growth in free cash flow for this management was after dividends. Free cash flow before dividends also grew at a nice pace. But nothing close to the headline that management put out.

The start of a stock purchase plan likely signals that there is a cushion developing that may later allow for a dividend increase. This dividend has not been increased in several years. But the growth in free cash flow shown above, combined with management's tendency to find good used deals on equipment (usually through bolt-on acquisitions), could mean that a dividend increase may finally be a possibility within the medium-term future.

Doing things this way means that if, for some reason, there is a cash flow decline, the dividend is very defensible in that the stock repurchase program can be eliminated first. This would also happen if capital needs increased.

Debt

The earnings press release also mentioned a debt upgrade that can lead to lower debt costs in the future.

The debt rating was upgraded at Moody's. With the current debt ratio among the lowest in the midstream industry, there could be more debt rating upgrades. The main customer, Antero Resources (AR) has been upgraded to investment grade.

That gives some room for more investment grades here. Both managements of Antero Resources and Antero Midstream have long explained that the highest debt rating that Antero Midstream can attain is whatever the major customer (Antero Resources) has for a debt rating.

Even though the debt rating is below investment grade, it is likely high enough to allow this company to use the debt market for whatever debt needs it has at a reasonable cost. While the rating is considerable somewhat speculative, it is at the higher end of the speculative range.

Map Of Operations

Antero Midstream has long grown a bit faster than the parent company. This is possible because the midstream operations never serviced the entire Antero Resources acreage.

The rig drilling on the dry gas acreage is using the capacity acquired a couple of years back, as shown above. There is still more room for growth using the available capacity.

Antero Resources management has long admitted to drilling rich gas acreage because it was more profitable to drill. But now things could be changing to the extent that the dry gas acreage could again be something to consider.

Antero Resources has also been purchasing subpar-sized positions that are right next to larger company positions. Some of these can be serviced in the future by Antero Midstream as well.

Summary

Midstream stocks often follow the upstream stocks, even though the midstream business itself is a very different business.

But despite the fact that this stock has appreciated considerably since 2021, there is likely still more appreciation potential as long as the natural gas pricing recovery continues.

The market has long not paid attention to the fact that this business is very steady and without a lot of upstream risks. There are take-or-pay provisions that assure a minimum.

Plus, this business does not service all of the Antero Resources business. It never has. Now, some acquisitions, like the capacity that serviced the dry gas acreage, have likely increased the percentage of the business serviced by Antero Midstream.

There is also the possibility that, as the midstream business grows, there could be more value-added businesses to consider. That could potentially make this company more of a "one-stop shop" for those customers where that is important.

On the other hand, this is one of the more richly priced midstream companies that I follow. Since there is a fear of a recession or worse due to the political uncertainty that exists. I would probably consider this a hold right now, even though I suspect there is still more long-term capital appreciation potential as long as natural gas prices continue to rise (long-term).

This company has a lot going for it. As such, I like everything but the stock price and the current market environment, that is caused by the political uncertainty. I intend to upgrade back to a buy as soon as this uncertainty that is causing the industry to "hunker down" goes away.

Risks

With a hold rating, there are both risks to the upside and to the downside to consider for such a decision.

On the downside, the threat of tariffs and trade wars, combined with still more political uncertainty, may bring about a recession or worse if this is not replaced by something permanent and constructive.

On the upside, a quick resolution of the current situation that would allow the economy to return to the growth mode that marked 2024 would be the upside risk.

The company also has a new CEO. While the previous CEO is still around, there is a transition underway that may also cause the stock price to wobble at times. The new CEO needs to establish his own record that is comparable to what was happening before he took the job.

Mutual Fund performance changes over time and currently may be significantly lower than stated above. Performance is updated and published monthly. Current month-end performance can be obtained at dodgeandcox.com or by calling 800-621-3979.

Market Commentary

Emerging market equities continued their strong performance during the third quarter. While U.S. stocks have recovered after stumbling earlier in the year, emerging market stocks have provided even higher absolute returns, as well as diversification benefits relative to other asset classes. China was particularly notable, as the MSCI China Index returned over 40% year to date. Its equity markets continued to benefit from domestic policy support and enthusiasm for technological breakthroughs in artificial intelligence (AI). South Korea has also been a market standout, benefiting from its key role in AI supply chains and improved political stability. Meanwhile, Latin American stocks continued to bounce back from 2024 with strong third quarter returns. Overall, the MSCI Emerging Markets had a total return of 10.6% for the third quarter and 27.5% year to date.

While emerging market valuations have risen to 14.0 times forward earnings, their valuation relative to the U.S. market has remained consistently compelling.2 The relative value of emerging market stocks compared to U.S. stocks is at one of the lowest levels over the past 20 years. Furthermore, spreads are extremely wide among emerging market equities, as measured by dispersions in sector and regional valuations. This presents attractive opportunities for price-disciplined investors.

Portfolio Strategy

As noted, China has been a stellar performer. Alibaba (BABA), China’s largest ecommerce and cloud computing platform, has been the Fund’s largest contributor to relative performance in 2025.3 However, the strength in the Fund’s Chinese holdings returns extends beyond internet-related names. Given the broad range of opportunity, we continue to diversify the Fund’s Greater China exposure.4 We established a position in DiDi Global (OTCPK:DIDIY), China’s dominant ride-sharing platform, during the second quarter, and the stock is up 48% as our thesis of profitability inflection materialized. In the third quarter, we initiated a position in Sungrow Power Supply, a leading global supplier of solar power systems and energy storage solutions. We also added to the Fund’s position in Greentown Service Group (OTCPK:GRTNF), a property management company with an attractive valuation, focused management team, and improved guidance for future profitability.

In terms of sectors, Energy and Industrials were the top two contributors to performance in the third quarter. In Energy, National Energy Services Reunited (NESR), an oilfield services company operating in MENA and Asia-Pacific returned over 70%, adding 120 basis points of relative value versus the Index. The stock detracted from results during the first half of the year, but we added to the Fund’s position because our knowledge of the company’s fundamentals gave us long-term confidence. Our willingness to add to positions in times of short-term volatility and uncertainty is a hallmark of our strategy. The Fund’s outperformance in the Industrials sector was led by positions in United Integrated Services, a Taiwanese engineering and construction services company, and Contemporary Amperex Technology (OTC:CTATF)[CATL], a Chinese lithium battery manufacturer.

Given the heightened unpredictability of current macroeconomic and geopolitical events, we expect continuing short-term volatility due to the nature of the emerging market landscape. Risks to the global economic and political order remain, including unknown effects of global tariff wars, increasing geopolitical risk in the Middle East, and volatile energy and commodity prices. Nevertheless, we continue to adhere to our disciplined investment approach and maintain our long-term investment horizon. Thank you for your continued confidence in Dodge & Cox.

Performance Review (Fund vs. MSCI Emerging Markets)

Third Quarter

Key contributors to relative results included the Fund’s:

  • Energy holdings—notably National Energy Services Reunited;
  • Industrials holdings, including United Integrated Services, CATL, and DiDi Global;
  • Underweight position in India;
  • Taiwanese dollar and Chinese renminbi currency hedges; and
  • Position in Millicom International Cellular (TIGO).

Key detractors from relative results included the Fund's:

  • Brazilian holdings, including Ambev (ABEV) and XP (XP), and overweight position in the country; and
  • Underweight positions in Tencent Holdings (OTCPK:TCEHY) and Samsung Electronics (OTCPK:SSNLF) and holding in HDFC Bank (HDB).

Year to Date

Key contributors to relative results included the Fund’s:

  • Underweight position and stock selection in India;

Key detractors from relative results included the Fund's:

data.title: Carvana Q3 Review: Subprime Lending Risks (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
Co-Authored by Noah Cox and Brock Heilig.

Investment Thesis

While Wednesday’s earnings report from used car giant Carvana Co. (CVNA) looks like a home run on the surface, I am becoming way more bearish on the online used car retailer since I first started writing on them last year, and especially since I last rated them a Strong Buy earlier this year in Q1.

To be clear, I continue to think Carvana has an innovative business model that should allow it to excel when compared with other used car retailers. The issue is, when we look under the hood, Carvana is supporting more and more of their business model with marking up and reselling used car loans they self originate.

In recent weeks, multiple subprime used car lenders have gone bankrupt here in the U.S. While I don’t think Carvana is heading towards bankruptcy, I do believe there's a huge risk: any further tightening of the used car loan market will mean Carvana could see one of its two sources of capital dry up.

Given that more than 100% of Carvana’s net income this year has come from gains on the sale of used car loans (to Wall Street and their partner, Ally Bank), I think there is significant net income risk going forward if the credit markets were to freeze.

For this reason, shares are double downgraded from a Strong Buy to a Hold.

Why I’m Doing Follow-Up Coverage

One of the biggest reasons why I am choosing to do follow-up coverage on Carvana now is because the Fed has cut interest rates 25 bps to 3.75%-4.00%. Post-earnings, this would normally be a game changer. However, I think there is a fundamental weakness underneath.

Lower borrowing costs typically directly stimulate auto financing, and because Carvana is a company that is heavily involved with e-commerce and auto loans, it normally would be able to capitalize greatly on the lower-rate environment.

As we’ve seen historically, even a 100 bps decline in loan rates has lifted auto sales growth.

However, in this case defaults are rising. I think Carvana is uniquely exposed to this. This could be really catastrophic. Post-earnings, this is why I am doing follow-up coverage.

Q3 Review

On the surface, Q3 looked solid. Carvana reported an EPS of $1.89/share, which beat estimates by $0.52. Revenues came in at $5.65 billion, which marked year over-year growth of 54.50% and beat estimates by $550 million.

We have to dig deeper to look at loan sales to really understand what drove the quarter, however.

As Jenkins, Carvana’s CFO, stated on the earnings call:

Non-GAAP other GPU increased by $63. This change was primarily driven by improvements in the cost of funds and higher finance and VSC attach rates, partially offset by higher-than-normalized loan sales relative to originations in Q3 2024.

I’ll get into why this is important later, but loan sales are a huge driver for Carvana’s profitability.

If we look at the rest of the gross profit per vehicle, we can see that overall gross profit declined for their vehicles they sold:

Non-GAAP retail GPU decreased by $77, primarily driven by higher retail depreciation rates. Non-GAAP wholesale GPU decreased by $168, primarily driven by higher wholesale depreciation rates and retail units sold growth outpacing ADESA marketplace growth -Q3 Earnings Call.

Defaults Are Rising, Carvana Is Exposed

To understand why Carvana is so exposed to marking up loans, we have to look at their most recent 10Q (filed this week).

In the 10Q, if we look at how much gain (profit) Carvana booked in Q3, we can see that more than 100% of the net profits the company earned in Q3 were driven from their gain of sale on their subprime loans:

The total gain related to finance receivables sold to financing partners and pursuant to securitization transactions was $331 million and $224 million during the three months ended September 30, 2025 and 2024, respectively, and $878 million and $541 million during the nine months ended September 30, 2025 and 2024, respectively, which is included in other sales and revenues in the accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated statements of operations -10Q.

For example, the company booked $331 million in gains on loans in Q3.

Their Q3 net income? $151 million.

These gains on loans are financed by Carvana selling their loans to two main groups: Ally Bank, and private pools of auto loans.

Increasingly, Ally Bank is a bigger chunk of the loan purchasing volume:

During the three months ended September 30, 2025 and 2024, the Company sold $1.2 billion and $0.7 billion, respectively, in principal balances of finance receivables under the Ally MPSA. During the nine months ended September 30, 2025 and 2024, the Company sold $3.2 billion and $2.15 billion, respectively, in principal balances of finance receivables under the Ally MPSA, and had $2.0 billion of unused capacity as of September 30, 2025 -10Q.

While this agreement with Ally Bank does not end until Q3 2026, there’s still risk here. Ally Bank is trusting that these pools of loans that Carvana is issuing don’t exhibit disproportionate levels of defaults. I think the risk here is that as the economy slows down (and as peers have shown), defaults are rising.

If Carvana were to lose access to their $6 billion purchase facility from Ally Bank, this could have a major impact on their long-run net income.

Recent subprime lender bankruptcies are pushing Wall Street to more closely examine their books of subprime loans.

Valuation

In the past, I thought Carvana’s valuation had some upside.

In fact, since I first rated the company a Strong Buy in September of 2024, shares have jumped over 125% as their revenues have picked up and consumers purchased more used cars from them.

As I have mentioned before, I think their service is incredible. That doesn’t mean they’re a high-quality stock anymore, however.

When I first rated the company a Strong Buy, I thought shares had 28% upside. The 128% return from there blew away my expectations.

Now, the valuation feels a little rich.

For example, the company’s non-GAAP forward P/E is now 56.46, which is 235.87% above the sector median of 16.81.

On the price-to-sales front, shares now trade at a 129.22% premium to the sector median. Keep in mind that when I originally rated the company a Strong Buy back in September of 2024, the price-to-sales multiple was at a 56% premium to the sector median.

In essence, the company’s valuation premium has more than doubled over the last year or so. This now feels extended to me.

In the past, when I rated the stock a Strong Buy, I had an idea what the fair value of shares was.

Now that I think shares are a Hold, I’m no longer sure what the fair value of shares are.

Bull Thesis

What’s interesting to me about this Fed interest rate cut this week is that (typically) in a lower-rate environment, affordability boosts demand. As of late, payments have become stretched. New car buyers are paying an average of about $756 per month for their vehicles, with one in five buyers paying more than $1,000 per month. Rate relief should allow for Carvana to benefit disproportionately.

The problem? Car sales in September and earlier this month have shown signs that used car prices continue to be an issue even as the Fed has cut interest rates and prices have stabilized. Cars are just too expensive now, even if interest rates are falling.

For Carvana, this presents another risk: Carvana could be stuck with tons of overpriced inventory. This was one of the major drivers that caused shares to drop significantly from 2021 until early 2023. There’s a risk that inventory could get mismatched with prices again.

Takeaway

To be clear, Carvana has huge potential with their online dealer business model. I still believe the company can have Amazon-like disruption potential for traditional brick-and-mortar used car dealers. But, this doesn’t mean the business model will be free of growing pains (we already are seeing this).

Carvana’s profits this year appear basically entirely supported by the gain on the sale of used car loans. This works great when the used car loan market is liquid and functional. Recent subprime lender bankruptcies remind us that this market can freeze up.

If we see the market freeze up, it's not unreasonable to assume that Carvana’s sources of capital to issue loans could dry up as well. This could be extremely challenging for their business.

With this, shares are now a Hold, downgraded from a Strong Buy.

data.title: Xylem: Solid Fundamentals Going Into FY2026
data.description:
Investment Summary

My previous investment thought on Xylem Inc. (XYL) was a buy rating because of the strong secular tailwinds that it benefits from. Also, the Evoqua integration and PFAS funding pipeline could be a major growth catalyst. My recommendation for XYL remains a buy rating, as it continues to deliver solid performance. In the Q3 2025 results, we can basically confirm that the 80/20 transformation strategy is working given the strong margins, growth, and EPS growth. With these secular tailwinds, strong execution, and order visibility, it all points to solid earnings growth ahead.

3Q25 Results Update

XYL's Q3 2025 results really proved my thesis right and were a textbook beat-and-raise quarter. Total revenue reached $2.3 billion, up 7% y/y on an organic basis, and importantly, growth was driven by all four segments. The outperformers were Measurement and Control Solutions (MCS), which grew 11% organically, and Water Solutions and Services (WSS), which grew 10% y/y. This flowed directly to margin expansion, driving adj. EBITDA margin to a record of 23.2%, up by 200 bps y/y. This strong margin, then, flowed through to drive adj. EPS up 23% y/y to $1.37.

The forward outlook also seems very positive, as management noted the business was “accelerating,” and the upward revision in guidance instilled confidence. Specifically, XYL raised its FY2025 revenue guide to ~$9 billion and also raised its profit targets. Adj. EBITDA margin is now guided to 22% to 22.3%, up sharply from the previous 21.3%–21.8% range, and the FY2025 adj. EPS guide was raised to $5.03–$5.08 versus the previous $4.70 to $4.85 range. At the midpoint, that implies a 6% lift.

The 80/20 Transformation Is Working

The 80/20 transformation that I talked about deeply previously has worked out really well, as expected. For those that did not follow my coverage, this 80/20 idea was simple but powerful. Basically, it is to focus resources on the top 20% of products and customers that drive profit and simplify or exit everything else. We know this is working because management explicitly noted the record-high margins were due to this very transformation. Even if you don’t believe management’s word, you can see it clearly in the legacy segments. Water Infrastructure delivered a very impressive 400 bps y/y expansion in adj. EBITDA margin, reaching 24.4%, while Applied Water, which was once a drag on profitability, improved by 310 bps y/y to 21.7%.

The transformation efforts go beyond just fixing legacy segments’ margins. The same transformation impact is playing out in portfolio optimization. The case in point is XYL’s divestiture of its international water and heat metering (IWHM) business, which is a deal that, in my view, perfectly illustrates this transformation in action. The IWHM business generated ~$250 million in 2024 revenue, but the adj. EBITDA margin was <10%, which means this is a drag on XYL’s overall margin. I view this exit favorably, as it achieves two things: (1) it structurally improves margin (due to mix impact), and (2) it allows XYL to allocate resources to its most profitable growth arena, which is the North American smart metering (AMI) market.

My view is that the North American market is where XYL has a right to win. In North America, XYL benefits from its proprietary Sensus FlexNet technology, which I think is a major competitive advantage. Unlike mesh networks that pass data from meter to meter, FlexNet is a private, point-to-multipoint network that operates on FCC-licensed radio frequency spectrum. Now, where it works in favor of XYL is that it owns this private spectrum. Owning this private network enables XYL to offer reliable long-distance data transmission that is secure. This means that XYL can reach nodes in the network (i.e., the meters) in remote and difficult locations (like in basements) far more effectively than competitors. And XYL can offer this while requiring less infrastructure, which lowers the total cost of ownership (TCO) for the utility customer.

I believe this edge gives XYL the right to capitalize on the ongoing replacement demand tailwind more than peers. As background info, the North American installed base of water meters is old, with many of them already past their useful life and needing to be replaced soon. Replacing is one demand driver, but the bigger driver is the type of replacement. Since the adoption of two-way AMI technology is still only at ~40% penetration, this means the majority of the market is still operating on the older, one-way meters. To explain it simply, the old one-way meter is just a "drive-by" system that utilities can only “collect” data from but cannot “ask” the meter questions. The new two-way AMI technology makes this possible. Utility customers can “ask” the meter on-demand for a real-time read, and the meter can respond with the right information. Think about the implication of this for a few seconds. It basically makes it possible for the utility customer to constantly monitor for leaks, pressure problems, or, at the very least, provide detailed usage data for analysis purposes.

MCS Order Strength De-Risks 2026 Growth

While total company orders declined 2% y/y organically, it wasn’t due to any structural weakness. It was simply due to very tough comps and softness in China. If you look beneath the headline numbers, you will find that the MCS (this is the segment that has the high-growth smart metering and AMI platforms in it) did extremely well. Orders managed to grow 11% y/y organically in Q3, despite the tough comps, which reflects the strong underlying demand.

As we lapse this tough comps period, FY2026 growth should be a lot more amazing. There is good visibility to this happening, as the MCS segment still sits on a healthy $1.5 billion backlog. Management was confident that the book-to-bill ratio will climb back to >1x in Q4 as major water-meter projects convert into firm orders. If that is true, growth is going to accelerate, and that supports the case for MCS to reach high-single-digit growth in 2026. Margins should also inflect as revenue ramps up because of mix impact. The margin expansion in Q3 was quite muted (just 60 bps y/y) because of lower-margin energy projects. Management noted that the core water business is performing at or above peer-level margins. The closest public peer to XYL is Badger Meter (BMI), which has an operating margin of ~20% in Q3.

Given that the <10%-margin international business is being sold, we should see the true earnings power of this segment soon.

Valuation

While XYL’s share price has risen, I still see a nice one-year 15% upside. Given the success with the 80/20 transformation, divestiture, and growth momentum, I upgrade my revenue growth assumption to 7% (high single digits) vs. mid-single digits previously. Management revised margin guidance (work backwards using adj. EPS guide * shares outstanding) also showed me that margin can inflect faster than I thought. As such, I upgraded my margin outlook to closer to mid-teens. All these upgrades justify XYL trading higher than what I expected previously (27x), which the market seems to agree with as well since XYL now trades at 29x. At 29x, I get to a share price target of ~$176.

Risk

The main risk is the slowdown in China, which was a 2% headwind to total company orders. This weakness, coupled with delays in UK funding cycles, ultimately drove a 2% y/y organic order decline. The problem is these are largely outside of XYL's control, and there is no guarantee that they will not get worse. If it does, overall organic orders could decline much further, and that could drag down performance again. Even with the $5 billion backlog that provides solid visibility, any delay in converting these large projects could create a temporary drag (or what one would term as an “air pocket”) in the quarterly results.

Conclusion

I maintain a buy rating for XYL. The strong Q3 performance, accelerating MCS orders, and solid progress with the 80/20 execution give a lot of confidence that revenue can grow and margin can expand. Overall, I still see upside, and the share price should reflect this as the market continues to recognize XYL’s improving fundamentals.

data.title: Pagaya: The Valuation Gap Is Too Wide Ahead Of A Likely Q3 Beat And Raise
data.description:
Over the past month, shares of Pagaya Technologies Ltd. (PGY) has cratered 15% on fears over the health of the US credit market following the bankruptcies of Tricolor and First Brands. Despite this, I believe the bullish thesis on Pagaya remains intact, especially ahead of its upcoming Q3 earnings.

With that in mind, several key Pagaya partners reported their Q3 earnings results recently, showing broader signs of strong loan demand and improving credit quality. This suggests that Pagaya may be on track to beat analysts’ estimates and raise its full-year outlook when it reports its Q3 earnings.

In my opinion, Pagaya’s partners’ results suggest that the credit environment in the US is stable and improving. This could be a sign of the US heading into a strong credit cycle over the coming quarters, especially with default rates stabilizing and beginning a gradual descent.

These signs of an improving credit environment could be supported by Barclays’ (BCS) latest expansion in the US personal lending market through its acquisition of Pagaya’s partner Best Egg, showcasing the attractiveness of the US credit market at the moment. Furthermore, Pagaya’s latest point of sale (POS) ABS transaction highlights the current favorable credit environment, in my opinion.

The transaction came with better funding terms, despite carrying riskier loans compared to the prior transaction, highlighting investors’ higher risk appetite and their growing confidence in Pagaya’s underwriting. In light of these factors, I’m reiterating my strong buy rating for Pagaya and raising my price target to $70, implying 168% upside from current levels.

Q3 Preview

Pagaya is set to report its Q3 earnings results on November 10th in pre-market, with analysts estimating the company to report revenues of $338.86 million and a GAAP EPS of $0.16. That said, I expect Pagaya could be on track for another beat and raise quarter in light of latest results from 3 of its key partners.

One of Pagaya’s key partners is SoFi (SOFI), which has recently reported impressive Q3 earnings driven by strong loan demand. During Q3, SoFi reported record loan originations of $9.9 billion, of which $3.4 billion were originated from its loan platform business, an all-time high. The latter fact is the most direct positive to Pagaya, in my opinion, since loans originated under SoFi’s loan platform business are the loans that are referred to Pagaya to give a second look using its AI platform.

Therefore, these record originations are likely to reflect on Pagaya’s network volume in Q3. Moreover, SoFi reported a net charge-off rate of 2.60% in Q3, down from 2.83% sequentially and 3.52% in the prior year. This implies a healthy personal loan borrower pool, as the improvement came along with higher loan volumes.

Another key Pagaya partner is US Bancorp (USB), which also reported solid Q3 earnings. During the quarter, the bank reported an average loan balance of $379.2 billion, representing growth rates of 1.4% YoY and 0.2% sequentially. The strong indicator for Pagaya’s upcoming earnings is that US Bank’s commercial loans, where consumer loans represented 27.3%, grew 9.5% YoY and 1.4% QoQ. This shows that US Bank is actively growing its consumer segment, a sign of an increased lending appetite, which could be a strong driver for Pagaya’s network volume when it reports Q3 earnings.

In similar fashion to SoFi, US Bank also saw an improving credit quality in Q3, as its net charge-off rate was 0.56%, 3 bps lower QoQ and 4 bps lower YoY. At the same time, the bank’s provision for credit losses represented 2.06% of its average loan balance, down from 2.07% and 2.12% in the prior quarter and year, respectively.

US Bank’s growing loan balance combined with better credit quality suggests that the bank is confident in the near-term credit outlook, which points to a healthy lending environment, in my opinion. The improving credit quality at US Bank could also serve as a tailwind for Pagaya's network volume in the coming quarters, potentially supporting the case for a guidance raise.

Shifting to auto loans, a segment Pagaya is rapidly expanding into, the company’s key partner in this segment, Ally Financial (ALLY), also reported strong Q3 earnings. During the quarter, Ally reported an all-time record 4 million applications for auto loans, with originations growing 25% YoY to $11.7 billion.

Ally’s record application volume is a significant positive for Pagaya, in my opinion, since it could provide it with a significant funnel of potential loans to analyze through its platform, which is a tailwind to network volume. With that in mind, 42% of Ally’s originations during Q3 were to its S-tier members, meaning that the majority of its originations came from lower tier borrowers. These lower quality borrowers include the higher risk borrowers that are usually given a second look through Pagaya’s platform.

As for credit quality, Ally reported a $230 million YoY reduction in its provision for credit losses during Q3. In my opinion, this could be a major sign of a better credit environment, as Ally expects better performance in its newer loan cohorts. In this way, Ally could increase its risk appetite in the coming quarters by offering loans to riskier borrower pools, which could drive additional network volume for Pagaya.

Improving Credit Environment

Aside from the company’s potential Q3 earnings beat, the longer-term credit environment appears to be trending favorably for Pagaya’s business, in my opinion. According to data from Apollo, US speculative grade default rates for loans appear to be stabilizing and in the process of falling from their peak, suggesting that the credit cycle is improving.

This improving backdrop could be a major tailwind for Pagaya, as an improving credit outlook supports favorable funding terms for Pagaya, as its loans could be perceived as of lower risk. This has actually occurred in Pagaya’s latest POS ABS transaction, POSH 2025-2, which is expected to close on November 7th.

The new ABS deal is for $300 million of loans backed by Klarna (KLAR) loan flow and includes better funding terms for Pagaya compared to its prior POSH 2025-1 ABS transaction, despite carrying a riskier loan pool. For starters, KBRA has a cumulative net loss expectation of 6.79% for this transaction compared to 5.01% in the company’s inaugural POS ABS transaction, as Class A notes are lower while other classes are higher in balance.

Despite the riskier loan pool, the latest transaction has a larger excess spread compared to the prior transaction at 24.02% compared to 22.43%. The higher excess spread was driven by a higher collateral interest rate at 31% compared to 30%, indicating that the profitability of these loans is greater than the previous pool. Moreover, the transaction has a lower coupon rate at 5.73% compared to 6.32%, reflecting strong investor demand despite the riskier loan pool and highlights investors’ growing trust in Pagaya’s underwriting.

Meanwhile, another sign of confidence in the health of the US credit environment and Pagaya’s own business model could be Barclays’ latest $800 million acquisition of Pagaya’s partner Best Egg to expand its US personal banking business. According to the Financial Times, Barclays expects this acquisition to provide it with access to more loans to bundle and sell them in ABS transactions, the same market Pagaya has been leading over the past few years.

In my opinion, Barclays’ venture into this market validates Pagaya’s asset-light approach and securitization model, which indicates that the company’s ABS transactions are likely to remain a strong growth driver over the coming years. At the same time, since Best Egg is already a Pagaya partner, this acquisition could provide Pagaya with an avenue to expand its footprint in new global markets through Barclays. While the company remains focused on serving the US market, a global expansion could serve as a new growth lever in case of a worsening credit cycle in the future.

Valuation

At its current share price of $26, Pagaya has a market cap of $2 billion, which translates to an EV of $2.48 billion after netting its $485.6 million in net debt. This means that the stock is trading at an EV/adjusted EBITDA multiple of 6.93 at the midpoint of its full-year adjusted EBITDA guidance of $357.5 million, compared to a sector median of 16.30.

Meanwhile, other high growth fintechs such as Upstart (UPST), Affirm (AFRM), Klarna, and Sezzle (SEZL) are trading at the following EV/EBITDA multiples.

In my opinion, this valuation gap compared to its peers suggests that the market may be underestimating Pagaya’s growth potential as the engine driving loan originations at banks and fintechs thanks to its platform. Therefore, I’m applying the sector median 16.30 EV/EBITDA multiple to Pagaya’s adjusted EBITDA guidance, which leads to my price target of $70, representing 168% upside from current levels.
