Risks

Although I’m bullish on Pagaya, a key risk to consider is the $870 million worth of loans it holds on its balance sheet. As an ABS issuer, Pagaya is obligated to retain at least 5% of the credit risk of the loans being securitized, per Dodd-Frank. These loans are typically of the lowest classes in its ABS transactions or the highest risk loans due to vertical retention.

While Pagaya has been increasing its non-ABS funding deals, including forward flow agreements, ABS issuances remain a key growth driver for the company. Therefore, if default rates increase and these loans perform poorly, the company may be forced to adjust the fair value of these loans downwards, leading to potentially significant losses. As is, the company currently previously incurred a $235 million impairment charge on its 2021-2023 loan vintages in Q4 2024, which had weighed on its valuation.

Conclusion

In summary, I believe Pagaya presents a compelling risk-to-reward profile ahead of Q3 earnings at its current valuation. With some of the company’s key partners recently reporting strong Q3 results, highlighted by strong personal loan demand and improving credit quality, the company could be well-positioned to exceed its network volume guidance, beat analysts’ estimates, and raise its full-year outlook.

Meanwhile, the longer-term credit environment appears to be promising for Pagaya, with US speculative grade default rates trending in the right direction, indicating an improving credit cycle, in my opinion. With that in mind, Pagaya’s latest POS ABS transaction could be a sign of an improving credit environment after the company secured more favorable funding terms compared to its prior transaction, despite carrying a riskier loan pool.

With the company's partners and investors appearing to have an increased risk appetite, Pagaya’s network volume may be well-positioned to sustain its growth rates in the short-to-medium terms. In my opinion, if Pagaya is able to achieve this feat while managing the risk of its originated loans through its underwriting, the stock could witness a rerating near other high-growth fintechs. It is for these reasons that I’m reiterating my strong buy rating for Pagaya and raising my price target to $70, representing 168% upside from its current valuation.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Apple's Record Quarter Won't Save You From Overpaying
data.description:
Thesis

In my last update on Apple Inc. (AAPL), I said investors should hold the stock. My reasoning was that Apple’s business itself looked strong, but the bigger picture wasn’t so friendly. Interest rates were going up, there were concrete data points showing that people were feeling less confident about the economy, and spending on nonessential items appeared to be slowing down, and that’s a challenging dynamic for a company like Apple, which depends on customers wanting its products, not needing them. Back then, I wasn’t sweating how Apple was managed, I was worried about the economy as a whole.

After looking at Apple's most recent earnings report, I think the company is still one of the world's most financially responsible and brand-resilient companies. However, the stock market has already factored that strength into the price, meaning investors are paying a premium for Apple’s excellence.

Apple Shows Strength in Services, Stability in Hardware

Let's jump right in. From a strategic standpoint, Apple focused on its strong products while dealing with changing global policies and currency fluctuations, yet Apple did what Apple usually does, and the company’s revenue reached $102.5 billion, that's an 8% increase from the same quarter last year, while EPS reached $1.85, both record highs for the September quarter.

Reading through the transcript, it’s clear that most of the improvement came from the sales mix. In essence, Apple sold more of its higher-margin products, which nudged its overall gross margin up by 0.7 percentage points to 47.2%. The Products division’s margin rose to 36.2%, while the Services division’s margin was 75.3%, a touch lower, slipping 0.3 percentage points from the previous quarter.

Moving on, let’s break it down by segment:

  • iPhone revenue: $49 billion, up 6% year over year. “We did set a September quarter record for upgraders,” said CEO Tim Cook. He also noted supply constraints on several iPhone 16 and 17 models.
  • Mac revenue: $8.7 billion, which is up 13% year over year. “We grew in every geographic segment with strong double-digit growth in emerging markets,” CFO Kevan Parekh said, adding that nearly half of Mac buyers were new to the product.
  • iPad revenue: $7 billion, flat year over year. “We faced a difficult compare against the full quarter impact of the iPad Air and iPad Pro launch from last year,” Parekh explained, though he highlighted that over half of iPad customers this quarter were new to the product.
  • Wearables, Home and Accessories revenue: $9 billion, flat year over year. “Both the Apple Watch and AirPods installed bases reached new all-time highs,” said Parekh.
  • Services revenue: $28.8 billion, up 15% year over year and an all-time record. “Our strong performance for the quarter is really organically driven,” Parekh added, emphasizing that growth came broadly across categories and geographies.

Before I go on, I want to say that I think Apple's numbers show a clear change in power toward its Services business. Hardware growth seems to be cooling off, however. Even though supplies were limited and the global economy was unstable, both the iPhone and Mac performed well, showing that Apple's loyal environment is still as strong as ever.

Meanwhile, the flat numbers for iPad and Wearables suggest those areas might be hitting a point of market saturation. But the record-breaking Services revenue tells us that Apple’s plan to build up steady, high-profit income from subscriptions and digital services is working exactly as intended.

Apple Manages Costs, Capital, and Growth with Precision

Apple’s Greater China sales fell 4% compared to last year, and management said most of that drop was due to limited iPhone supply, not weaker demand. Even though sales are down, more people are going into stores in China, which is a good omen for future sales. Looking ahead, Apple’s management expects sales in China to grow again in the December quarter. They also said that local government subsidies are helping to boost sales. However, these programs only cover certain iPhone models that are priced at certain levels, so not all devices can get the discount.

The CFO said that costs are following the usual pattern. Prices for memory parts have dropped a bit, which helps a little. However, at the start of a new product cycle, the cost of materials is usually higher until the company finds ways to make things more efficiently.

Apple spent around $1.1 billion on tariffs this quarter, which matched what they had expected. I want to stop here for a second, because even with more than a billion in tariffs, Apple still posted record revenue and profit this quarter, a sign of just how tightly the company runs its operation. Given current trade policies, Apple expects tariff costs to climb to around $1.4 billion for the December quarter. This estimate also considers recent changes in tariff rates, which is why Apple says tariff costs won’t increase in direct proportion to how many products they sell.

Meanwhile, management also said that investments in Private Cloud Compute for Apple Intelligence will cause capital spending to go up. One of these is that brand-new data center in Houston that's already sending servers out. Apple said it will stick with a plan that uses both its own facilities and those of outside companies.

At the end of the quarter, the company had $132 billion in cash and assets, around $99 billion in debt, and $34 billion in net cash, which is after paying off its debts. During the quarter, Apple gave $24 billion back to shareholders, which includes $20 billion through stock buybacks and $3.9 billion in dividends. Also, to shareholders who own the stock as of November 10, the Board announced a dividend of $0.26 per share, which will be paid on November 13.

Apple expects its revenue for the December quarter to grow by 10% to 12% compared to the same time last year, with iPhone sales rising by double digits. The company also projects a gross margin of 47% to 48%, that, by the way, already factors in about $1.4 billion in tariff costs. Operating expenses are expected to be between $18.1 billion and $18.5 billion, other income and expenses (OI&E) should be around $150 million, and the tax rate is estimated at 17%.

Apple’s Building the Future of AI on Its Own Terms

Before I go into valuation, I want to circle back and cover some more background on how Apple is spending more money to grow its Private Cloud Compute system, which uses its own custom computer chips. The company is also moving more of its AI processing to its M-series devices, like Macs and iPads. Apple said that its new AI servers, built right here in the United States, act as backup power for on-device AI when bigger computing power is needed.

Essentially, Apple describes Private Cloud Compute as a privacy-first system. It uses verified software that can’t be changed without approval, doesn’t keep any long-term data, and has a program where outside researchers can check the exact software before it’s allowed to process real user activity.

This, as you know, isn't exactly common for big tech companies. It also shows that Apple likes a hybrid strategy, where most private work stays on your device and only the bare minimum is sent to its tightly controlled cloud.

Regarding performance, it comes as no surprise that Apple is gearing up its devices to handle more AI work locally. The new M5 chip generation has more than 4x as much peak GPU power for AI as its predecessor. It also packs a faster Neural Engine and more memory bandwidth, letting devices handle bigger AI jobs, things like parsing longer conversations or combining text, images, and audio, without leaning so much on the cloud.

As such, the takeaway is that every bit of processing that happens directly on your iPhone, iPad, or Mac instead of Apple’s servers helps cut cloud costs, improves latency, and fits Apple’s strong stance on user privacy. So when your device can’t handle a request on its own, Apple’s new Houston servers step in under the same security guarantees and apparently erase all data once the job is done.

Personally, I believe this makes a big difference because it helps Apple keep its profits high (hence, SA's A+ profit grade) and makes the brand stronger against the effects of its current and future competitors. Apple saves money on outside computer costs by doing more AI processing on its own devices and only using its own cloud when it needs to. It also makes Apple's image for protecting privacy stronger, which keeps users and lawmakers on board.

Meanwhile, earlier this year, the company said it’s committing over $500 billion in U.S. spending over the next four years, with AI infrastructure and chipmaking near the top of the list. So while building and assembling servers in Texas helps keep the supply chain tighter, parts and upgrades will move faster while also insulating Apple a bit from trade tensions abroad. It also means Apple can control its upgrade pace instead of depending completely on outside GPU suppliers. All very practical moves, though they also happen to make for good PR in the current political climate too, about “investing in America.”

From an investor’s perspective, Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) and Google (GOOG) (GOOGL) largely depend on extensive shared GPU cloud infrastructures to support their AI tools. Apple's hybrid route, meanwhile, could boost Apple’s Services revenue without depending on the same cost structure as full-blown cloud AI providers. All things considered, you can look at it this way: instead of charging users to “rent” AI power, Apple bakes new AI features right into iOS, iPadOS, and macOS, encouraging people to upgrade their devices rather than pay per use.

AAPL’s Valuation

I’m valuing Apple based on its earnings and how it compares to other companies in the same industry. At a share price of $271.40, Apple’s blended P/E ratio is 36.44x its earnings, which is well above its 5-year forward average of 28.56x (see below) and higher than the industry average of 25.56x.

The same pattern shows up in other measures too, with Apple’s EV-to-EBITDA ratio at 26.25x (see below) compared to the sector’s 15.68x, and its EV-to-sales ratio is 8.87x versus the sector’s 3.63x.

FAST Graphs shows us that AAPL is much higher than what its fundamentals suggest.

I always take this with a heavy grain of salt, but using a fair value multiple of 15x earnings, the stock would be worth significantly lower, about $111.72. So even if we use the “normal” multiple of 27.57x, there’s still room for the valuation to come down as analysts expect EPS to grow around 10% a year through 2026–2028.

Clearly, buying here means paying that AAPL "premium price" that’s growing its revenue in the high single digits and its earnings in the low teens.

I think it's a fair argument that the high valuation assumes both the illustrious brand name and, in the fundamentally practical sense, Apple’s Services segment, which can easily keep growing at a steady mid-teens pace, and that overall profit margins will stay around 47 to 48%, as the company has guided. It also assumes Apple can handle the costs of investing in AI without hurting its free cash flow or the valuation investors give it.

Final Takeaway

I'm keeping my Hold rating. I love the brand. It's all I use. It's all my family uses, and most everyone I know too. At its core, Apple’s brand and product ecosystem are second to none, and its growing Services business, along with new AI investments, should keep its cash flow strong over time.

However, with AAPL stock trading at about 36x earnings and carrying higher valuation ratios than most of its peers, buying more shares now means paying a steep price for that strength. I’d rather stay patient and look to add on multiple compression or a reset.

data.title: Logitech: Margins Still Strong, But Value Proposition Is No Longer There
data.description:
Logitech International S.A. (LOGI) is a designer and manufacturer of consumer computer hardware, including keyboards, mice, microphones, cameras, and other computer peripherals. The Swiss company was founded in 1981 and has around 7,300 employees with a market capitalization of around $11.4 billion. This puts it in the top 15 companies in technology hardware and peripherals. This part of information technology can often be forgotten, as software and AI-related companies get the most attention. Most importantly, the stock is in the consumer discretionary category, which suggests it may be more sensitive to the cyclicality of the economy.

Revisiting November 2024 Analysis

Since my last analysis was published about a year ago, LOGI bounced from trading down -9.4% in the year through November 2024 to increasing over 50% through the end of October 2025. In that piece, I highlighted Logitech’s improving profitability and operational discipline as signs that the market was undervaluing the company’s long-term potential. The core message was that margin expansion, product innovation, and growing exposure to the education market were reshaping its fundamentals even as headline revenue growth remained uneven. Here are the key points from that analysis:

  • Profitability had become Logitech’s defining strength, with gross margins rising to around 43.6% (the highest since early 2021) as cost reductions and a better product mix drove consistent improvement. The company achieved five straight quarters of margin gains, signaling durable progress in its pricing power and expense control.
  • The company’s innovation, particularly in gaming and creative peripherals, showcased its ability to differentiate in both mature and emerging markets. These launches helped reinforce LOGI’s reputation as a premium brand rather than a low-cost manufacturer. Additionally, rapid growth in tablet accessories tied to schools and digital learning highlighted the success of LOGI’s move into the education sector. Management viewed this vertical expansion as a model for extending the brand into other specialized markets.
  • China remained both a challenge and an opportunity, as demand softness and competition weighed on short-term results while local product strategies and supply chain diversification laid the groundwork for recovery. LOGI’s measured approach balanced near-term caution with long-term positioning in a critical market.

The primary motivation behind my buy recommendation a year ago was a favorable valuation after the stock had dropped in the month and year before. Despite the clear fundamental improvement, the stock traded with a P/E ratio around 17-18x, below its five-year average of 22x. That mismatch between fundamentals and valuation made it clear that LOGI had significant upside. As mentioned before, LOGI has seen a strong run in the past year, outperforming the S&P 500 (SP500) with gains of just over 45%. That demands a reassessment of the value proposition and, potentially, an update to the rating.

FYQ2 2026 Earnings

LOGI recently released its FYQ2 2026 earnings, which cover its results for Q3 2025. The stock continued its run of earnings beats, reporting non-GAAP EPS of $1.45, a healthy beat over Wall Street expectations of $1.23. Its revenue numbers are typically a bit closer to consensus, and in FYQ2 2026, LOGI met expectations with revenue of $1.19 billion.

Importantly, its growth rates of revenue and profits were both positive. Total revenue increased 6% YoY in U.S. dollar terms and 4% YoY in constant currency terms, the strongest increase so far this calendar year, with five business segments expanding and three business segments declining. The sales growth helped contribute to an increase of 19% YoY in operating income, also the strongest so far this calendar year.

Sales Growth

Regional performance was mixed, with strong international gains offsetting softness in the Americas. Sales in the Americas declined -4% YoY in constant currency, weighed down by weakness in Gaming and Tablet Accessories, though Pointing Devices saw healthy growth. EMEA delivered a 3% YoY increase, supported by solid demand across segments. The clear standout was Asia Pacific, where sales rose 19% YoY, marking a second consecutive quarter of double-digit growth. Strength was broad-based in this region as well, highlighting improving sell-through momentum and successful new product uptake in the region. In fact, the overall increase in sell-through relative to net sales growth (10% YoY vs. 6% YoY) points to stable consumer demand despite weakness in LOGI’s main region. Across product lines, growth was led by Logitech’s core Personal Workspace and Gaming segments, picking up the slack in some smaller segments:

  • Gaming revenue grew 5% YoY in constant currency, driven by PC Gaming and strong Asia-Pacific results. Notably, demand in the Americas was softer due to market weakness and pricing adjustments related to tariffs. Despite that, LOGI announced 12 new products in this segment, showing its commitment to innovation in the face of uncertainty.
  • Within its Personal Workspace product group, Keyboards & Combos and Pointing Devices both posted 10% YoY growth (constant currency), supported by double-digit expansion in EMEA and Asia Pacific and the launch of new premium models. LOGI continues to maintain its top position in these markets, which is key in uncertain times.
  • Beyond Gaming and Personal Workspace, smaller segments struggled. Video Collaboration grew 3% YoY, with premium products lifting average selling prices, while Webcams rose 2% YoY, maintaining market leadership despite a modest decline in Asia Pacific. Tablet Accessories slipped -3% YoY after a strong prior-year comparison, and Headsets fell -8% YoY due to transitioned product lines.

Overall, the mix of gains in core categories and strong international growth reinforced the company’s leadership in premium peripherals. LOGI has consistently shown that its diversification across the computer peripheral market is its strength. For example, management noted in the conference call that its B2B segments performed well while consumer segments were a bit soft, and similarly, the growth in Asia Pacific picked up some of the slack of the North American markets. I believe this has been key to its consistency in earnings results over the last few years.

Profitability

While it’s always good to see solid top-line growth, the storyline for 2025 has been about profit margins. Tariffs have created a challenging environment for managing costs and compressed margins in the first two quarters of the year, and that has called into question one of my main motivations for rating the stock as a Buy. However, results in FYQ2 2026 earnings have shown LOGI’s resilience. Non-GAAP gross margins were down -30 bps YoY to 43.8% in FYQ2 as tariff costs weighed, but this was a significant improvement of 170 bps over gross margins of 42.1% in FYQ1 (which were down -120 bps YoY). Further down towards the bottom line, non-GAAP operating margins were reported to have increased 210 bps YoY to 19.4% in FYQ2 (up 180 bps QoQ), an even more impressive showing of operational efficiency. Management highlighted two key reasons for the preservation of its margins:

  • LOGI focused on cutting costs where they could control them, specifically in SG&A and marketing expenses, such that operating expenses actually declined -3% YoY to be about 24.4% of total sales, a drop of -240 bps from the same quarter a year ago. This was part of a successful plan put in place by management to offset the impact of the tariffs.
  • Another way LOGI sought to find relief from tariffs was by diversifying its supply chains. Management reported that it was continuing to find ways to source a few North American goods from China and was “on track to reduce our share of U.S. products originating from China to 10% by the end of this calendar year.”

I continue to be impressed by LOGI's ability to convert healthy sales growth into strong profitability, while maintaining a reputation for developing premium products for consumer and business customers (releasing 16 new products in the last quarter). Wall Street seems to consistently underappreciate this facet of LOGI’s fundamentals, which is why we see earnings beats consistently, even while revenues are estimated pretty well by analysts. It does appear that the worst of the volatility in U.S. trade policy is likely behind us, and tariff rates have more or less reached their ceilings. With that in mind, further gross margin compression is likely to become less of an issue.

FYQ2 2026 earnings ended with an outlook for the final quarter of 2025, the most important quarter for LOGI since it includes the holiday season. The outlook sees sales growth similar to what was seen in FYQ2 and an increase of about 5.2% YoY in operating income. Management’s feelings about the upcoming quarter can be described as cautiously optimistic. CFO Matteo Anversa summarized the sentiment well in his comments about the outlook.

We believe we will see continued strong momentum in our business, but we also see some market uncertainty. The North American consumer market, especially in gaming, was softer in Q2... We're cautiously optimistic that this will improve for the holiday season, but that is, of course, yet to be confirmed.

Holiday Season Uncertainty

Yes, the holiday season is the biggest question mark for LOGI, especially in its largest North American segment. That segment already saw sales decline in FYQ2, and the macroeconomic fundamentals, especially in the US, suggest that we will likely see a similar trend in FYQ3. In my previous analysis, I highlighted how LOGI would likely see a strong holiday quarter due to healthy consumer fundamentals, especially among younger demographics that are more likely to spend on electronics. But that tailwind has quickly flipped into a headwind due to the deterioration of the labor market in 2025, especially for LOGI’s key younger demographic.

In the U.S., we have seen nonfarm employment growth slow down significantly, even seeing a month of job losses in June. The slowdown in hiring has been felt across the labor market, but it has particularly impacted younger populations. Research from Vanguard shows that employment growth has indeed slowed in the 26-40 and 41-55 age groups, but the deceleration has been the sharpest in the 21-25 age group, falling from a peak of 5.7% in 2022 to just as of September 2025. This decline in employment growth translates to a decline in income growth, and Vanguard has tracked this trend in its own analysis (from 401(k) contribution data).

Another analysis from NCCI about unemployment rates reports a more troubling result:

“In August, the unemployment rate for younger workers reached 10.5%, compared to an unemployment rate of just 3.6% for prime age workers (25–54 years old).”

The data on both hiring and joblessness are pretty consistent in pointing out that younger consumers are having more trouble in the labor market.

As a result of this trend, I believe that FYQ3 2026 (and beyond) will be difficult for LOGI, and the softness in North American demand will weigh on its headline sales growth. This ties back into the simple fact that the company is a member of the consumer discretionary sector, which makes it sensitive to these moments in the business cycle. This is especially the case in a quarter that relies heavily on demand from the holiday season.

China Is Still Critical

While North America remains the main source of weakness, strength in the Asia Pacific, and especially in China, has become a key offset. The “China for China” strategy continues to deliver, with double-digit regional growth driven by strong local demand and a steady cadence of new product launches.

China has been the standout, leading global gaming sales thanks to the success of local products and more targeted, high-ROI marketing campaigns. Management also noted that China’s performance was ahead of the broader Asia Pacific region, which already grew 19% YoY in FYQ2. These results show that LOGI’s localized strategy and strong brand presence in China are paying off, and continued momentum in Asia Pacific could help cushion the impact of softer US demand heading into the next few quarters.

Although, the Chinese economy is feeling the effects of the U.S. tariff policy, creating a tougher macro environment for LOGI. Retail sales growth has slowed from a near-term peak of 6.5% YoY in May 2025 to just 3.0% YoY in September 2025, the weakest since November 2024. This is likely based in weaker income growth so far this year, as estimated by McKinsey. An analysis completed in Q2 2025 suggested that household income growth would only be about 1.4% in 2025, down from 2.5% YoY, and while that didn’t necessarily translate to weaker expected consumption, LOGI’s products being more discretionary suggests it is likely to see more of a headwind in weaker income growth. Nevertheless, LOGI’s management has more visibility into its own Chinese markets, and its market positioning might shield it from broader macro weakness.

Revisiting The Value Proposition

With LOGI running up over 45% in the last year and FYQ2 operating income reported up around 19% YoY, there has been a significant increase in its valuation over that time period. The market has (rightfully) readjusted its pricing of sales up from 2.8x about a year ago to 3.9x today and its pricing of earnings up from 17.7x a year ago to around 27.4x today. Comparatively, this puts its P/S ratio at the highest levels since 2021, and its P/E ratio at the highest since early 2024 (still below the peak valuations in late 2023).

Importantly, these valuation changes haven’t come about from weaker fundamentals, but rather from the market adjusting (appropriately) to LOGI’s consistently better-than-expected margin results. Unfortunately, this makes the stock much less of a value opportunity, and Seeking Alpha’s Quant ratings reflect that, as the valuation grade has moved from B- six months ago to a D- now (though the P/E ratio comparison is still rated a B).

After its latest earnings, LOGI is now trading above $120, the highest since the stock peaked above $130 during the COVID lockdown period. I like this company’s fundamentals, as it showcases why strong and consistent margins are an important factor that can lead to outperforming the broader market. However, because the valuations have increased and macro conditions have started to become unfavorable in its key North American market (especially for its key upcoming FYQ3 quarter), I am downgrading my LOGI rating from a Buy to a Hold.

data.title: Since 1800, The Market Has Taught This Lesson, But Few Learn
data.description:
Investment Thesis

I reiterate my buy recommendation on assets that track the main American indices. This article is a continuation of my initial coverage article published on November 5, 2024, and my last article in the series was published on October 20, 2025.

In this article, I will bring more data and insights to demystify bubble narratives. Additionally, we will see that since 1800, it is not very smart to wait for an asset to return to its historical average before buying, especially in the context of the current economy. Finally, we will analyze seasonality for investments in November.

Demystifying Narratives

Honestly, it is increasingly difficult to believe in a bubble in the current scenario. I say this based on a basic concept: bubbles occur when no one expects them, and the increase in searches for "AI Bubble" on Google simply does not match this elementary concept.

But of course, you can argue that a big market risk is the concentration of earnings in a few companies. However, the graph below shows that only the industrial and utilities sectors received flows considered speculative. The technology sector saw a large expansion in earnings, which explains its prices at historic levels.

The same error occurs when the investor tries to analyze the Magnificent Seven through the P/E. We must remember that this metric does not capture well the growth rates and expansion capacity of their businesses. Additionally, the chart below shows that these companies are trading at a 25% premium to the S&P 500, and this level is below the 40% average over the last five years.

Insight of the Week

Every week I write articles about investments and the American economy, and there is always a graph that catches my attention the most. This week, I bring extremely interesting information about the perception of buying when an asset returns to its historical average. I say this because a major objection for investors when purchasing assets that replicate the main American indexes is waiting for an eventual return to the average.

Unfortunately, research over the last 225 years (since 1800) shows that one sector can dominate the market for up to 50 years. Therefore, you should not wait for technology and artificial intelligence stocks to return to their historical average, as they may take a long time to correct. Additionally, when the price of these shares returns to its historical average, it is probably no longer the best time to invest.

General Scenario Supports Optimistic View

In addition to all the graphs listed above that refute any bubble thesis, the investor just needs to make a cold analysis of the economic scenario, and they will see the opportunity. As we can see below, the presidents of China and the United States have signed a commercial agreement that seems very beneficial for the investment scenario.

In parallel to the news above, the Fed continues to cut interest rates, which historically boosts the stock market. Additionally, since 2021, American companies have not surprised as positively as they have now. The corporate results of these companies have surprised the market and boosted prices.

Still talking about profits, we can see in the graph below that American companies have systematically achieved margin gains since 1990; that is, current profit margins are consistent with reality.

Seasonality and Target

To conclude my argument, there is a great invitation for skeptical investors to change their opinion. Over the past 50 years, November has been the highest-returning month in the S&P 500, and over the past 20 years, November has been the second-best month. Therefore, in addition to all the arguments mentioned, seasonality is also favorable.

Based on all the insights in this article, I reiterate the recommendation to buy assets that track the main American indices. My target for the S&P 500 is 7,095 points. Additionally, for investors who prefer a portfolio with strategically chosen assets, I offer my recommended stock portfolio for 2025. Year-to-date, the portfolio is up 23.2%, while the S&P 500 is up 16.4%.

Potential Threats To The Thesis

There are several risks to the thesis. Despite all the arguments mentioned, research carried out with fund managers shows that there is an increase in the perception of an AI bubble.

Another risk concerns the Shiller P/E. This indicator weights profits by inflation, which smooths economic cycles. Right now, the stock market is approaching the Shiller P/E levels of the 2000s, when the dot-com bubble occurred.

Another interesting fact to monitor is the weakness of the job market, especially after the Fed indicated that further interest rate cuts are not that likely. It is necessary to carefully analyze the impact that artificial intelligence will have on the economy and the job market.

The Bottom Line

As I mentioned in this article, it is increasingly difficult to believe in bubble narratives, especially regarding their fundamental concept. A bubble occurs when few notice it, and this is not the behavior that investors currently demonstrate.

On the other hand, we have a great revolution taking place: artificial intelligence. Without a doubt, this technology will have major impacts on the economy, but it will also bring an increase in margins for many companies, which should continue to boost the S&P 500.

Based on this analysis, I reiterate the recommendation to buy assets that replicate the main American indexes. As we saw in this article, investors who wait for assets to return to their historical average will probably wait a while longer.

data.title: Forecasting Bond Fund Returns In A Post-2021 Regime Isn't Getting Any Easier
data.description:
By James Picerno

Developing reliable return expectations for bonds is straightforward, at least compared with the far greater uncertainty associated with stocks. But the relative reliability for projecting performance with fixed-income securities is closely linked to buying and holding a bond through its maturity date. Results over shorter periods can and often do vary substantially. Investing in bond funds introduces more return variability vs. the implied outlook with a relevant buy-and-hold position in an individual Treasury security or corporate bond.

A high degree of clarity for expected return with bonds is a function of using the current yield at the time of purchase as a forecast. For example, a 5-year Treasury Note is currently trading around 3.7%. Assuming you purchase the security directly at that current yield and hold it through maturity, the performance will roughly match the yield at the time of purchase. (Technically, yield-to-maturity, which factors in additional variables, is a more accurate measure for projecting return, but for simplicity in this illustration, let’s assume current yield is equivalent. Note, too, that we’re ignoring such issues as how you invest a bond’s payouts through time and other variables, such as callable bonds and defaults that affect returns for corporates.)

Investing in bonds by way of a fund adds another layer of complication that can, and usually does, affect performance - sometimes in ways that aren’t intuitive. As an example, consider a buy-and-hold investment in Vanguard Total Bond Market Index Fund (VBMFX), a popular mutual fund that holds investment-grade securities.

Morningstar reports that a bit more than half of VBMFX’s portfolio is held in US government bonds, with corporates (25%) and securitized bonds making up most of the rest (22%). The fund’s yield to maturity is 4.38%.

Assume the 5-year Treasury yield is a proxy for the fund, which implies that when you bought VBMFX, the current 5-year rate is a reasonable first approximation of what you can expect to earn over the next 5 years. The broader portfolio holdings in VBMFX will create differences vs. a 5-year Note, but current yield for the government security should be a decent back-of-the-envelope forecast.

Sometimes that’s a reasonable assumption, but it can also be wide of the mark. Much depends on current macro conditions and the outlook when you buy VBMFX.

For context, the chart below compares the 5-year annualized total return for VBMFX five years hence relative to the 5-year yield. If the 5-year yield was a perfect forecast for VBMFX’s return five years down the road, the two lines would match exactly. Clearly, that’s not the case. Although there are periods when the 5-year yield (red line in chart) is a reasonably accurate estimate of the future 5-year return for VBMFX (black line), there can be substantial divergences for prolonged periods.

For most of VBMFX’s history, the fund has outperformed or matched the 5-year yield. But since the Federal Reserve’s latest round of rate hikes starting in 2022, VBMFX’s five-year return has trailed the 5-year yield (from five years earlier) by a relatively wide margin for an extended period.

There are several possible reasons for the mismatch in recent years, including the rapid pace of 2022-2023 rate hikes, the lingering effects of the pandemic on the economy, and the sharp spike in inflation in 2022-2023.

Another relevant factor: the four-decade trend of generally declining interest rates that ended in 2021. Forty years of falling yields bred a high degree of comfort in assuming that risk was minimal for the bond market’s outlook. When that regime ended, the shift introduced more uncertainty and volatility into the market to a degree unseen in decades.

Even before 2021, it was unsurprising that VBMFX’s rolling 5-year return deviated from the implied forecast via a 5-year yield. The fund, although it tracks an index, holds a range of bonds and therefore takes more risk vs. a Treasury note. The higher risk mostly paid off, until the 2022 rate hikes.

The larger point is that developing return and risk expectations for bond funds has become considerably more nuanced. By contrast, forecasting VBMFX and other bond strategies was more or less pro forma in the pre-2021 era, with relatively low stakes given the general slide in yields.

That era ended in 2022, and it’s debatable when or if it will return. Between tariffs, gridlock in government, elevated fiscal risk for the US government, and the potential for AI-fueled economic disruption, a repeat performance of the secular slide in interest rates during 1981-2021 looks unlikely, at least at the moment.

In turn, the stakes are higher for crunching the numbers and reading the trends for developing expectations for bond funds.

Buying and holding a Treasury note, by comparison, still offers simplicity and relative reliability for projecting future performance.

Original Source: The Milwaukee Company

data.title: Carvana: Buy The Earnings Drop (Upgrade)
data.description:
One of the best turnaround stories has been Carvana (CVNA). The used car retailer, which some like myself thought could go bankrupt just a few years ago, has been one of the best-performing stocks in recent years. On Wednesday, the company announced its third-quarter results, and while the stock dropped afterwards, there were certainly many things to like.

Previous Coverage Of The Name

It's been about two and a half years since I last covered Carvana, at which point I remained a major skeptic. At that time, revenues were falling as the company was pulling back on inventory to stem major cash burn, and the balance sheet was in terrible shape. With a so-so margin picture and not much room to grow in the near term, the once booming stock traded for just around $11 a share. With things improving significantly since, this has been one of the market's biggest rallies, up over 2,700%, compared to a 65% gain for the S&P 500.

A Look At The Q3 Results

For the September ending period, Carvana announced retail units sold of 156,000, or more than 44% growth over the prior year period. With some help from average selling prices, the company reported record quarterly revenue of $5.65 billion. This number was up 55% year over year, and it crushed street estimates by more than $550 million. Total revenues have more than doubled from where they were just two years earlier. Thanks to seven straight quarterly revenue beats and management's hope to get to 3 million annual deliveries within 5 to 10 years, analyst revenue estimates for future years have soared, as seen in the table below.

The biggest key to the ongoing turnaround has been major cost management. As the company has worked to integrate the ADESA sites it acquired over time, along with reducing operating expenses per unit, overall margins have improved tremendously. In Q3 2022, for instance, gross margins were 10.6%, and operating margins were negative 15%. In the just reported quarter, however, those numbers had jumped to 20.3% and a positive 9.8%, respectively. On the operating side, that's more than $1 billion of improvement. Even with gross margins down 175 basis points year over year, management was still able to drive a 55-basis-point increase for its operating margins.

As revenues continue to grow over time, the bottom line could look even better. While the gross margin percentage may not rise every single quarter, gross margin dollars should benefit from the top-line increase. It also appears that as the company continues to sell more vehicles, it may be able to reduce operating expenses as a percentage of revenue another percentage point or two. Finally, interest expenses were still running at a half-billion-dollar pace in Q3 2025, and annual positive cash flow moving forward will help to bring those payments down further from the nearly $700 million run rate peak they were at in early 2024.

Major Balance Sheet Improvement

My biggest concern back in the day was the company's balance sheet. With the company losing money for a time, and also spending wildly to grow, cash burn was extremely high. Just two and a half years ago, net debt was nearly $8 billion, and there was a lot of talk about a potential bankruptcy. Carvana struck a major debt deal with lenders, and since then, the situation has improved tremendously, as seen in the chart below.

At the end of September, the net debt figure was down to just around $3 billion. Total cash was more than $2.1 billion, while total debt stood at just over $5.2 billion. The company has diluted investors a bit over the years to help with its debt pile, but it shouldn't need any substantial equity raises moving forward unless it is for a major acquisition. With the surge in shares in recent years, even a couple of percent of dilution now would wipe out a significant amount of the company's remaining debt.

Free cash flow in the first 9 months of the year was just over half a billion dollars. While that was down from nearly $800 million in the first three quarters of last year, it was mainly due to an extra $522 million spent on inventory. Positive cash flow will allow for more debt repurchases, and as mentioned on the conference call, another nearly $100 million worth of notes were bought back in October.

Valuation Is High, But It Has Certainly Come Down

With Thursday's more than 13.8% drop, Carvana currently has a market cap of about $66.5 billion. Based on current revenue estimates, that means the stock trades for about 2.67 times next year's projected revenue. That is a major premium to names like CarMax (KMX) and AutoNation (AN), who both go for about 0.25 times their projected 2026 sales. However, those two names are projected for very limited revenue growth, while Carvana is seeing its top line soar.

With shares of Carvana about $100 off their 52-week high, and revenue estimates jumping as shown above, that valuation has certainly improved. The stock was going for well over 4 times next year's expected sales just a few months ago. As pointed out in the company's shareholder letter, growth currently dwarfs the industry (44% unit growth in Q3 vs. 0% average), and margins are considerably higher (11.3% Adjusted EBITDA vs. 5.0% average).

Wall Street analysts are also very positive on the name currently. As of Thursday morning, 14 of the 22 analysts covering the name had either a "Buy" or "Strong Buy" recommendation on the stock, with just one "Strong Sell," and seven holds. The average price target as of Thursday night was just about $424, implying nearly 39% upside from current levels.

Final Thoughts And Recommendation

While Carvana shares tumbled on Thursday, the company's Q3 report showed just how much of a turnaround has been completed here. No longer is the company losing money and burning through large amounts of cash. Revenue growth is soaring with decent margins, and positive cash flow has helped to significantly improve what was once a hideous balance sheet.

With the company having just 1.5% market share currently, there is plenty of room for future growth, especially given a lack of meaningful presence in some areas of the country, seen below. Just a doubling of market share would put the company over a million retail units sold a year, and management hopes to get well beyond that in the next decade.

While the valuation here certainly is high compared to peers, you aren't going to get this kind of growth elsewhere in the space. With Carvana's worst days behind it, I think this pullback provides an opportunity for those looking to "buy," and thus that will be my new rating here today. I was definitely one of the company's biggest skeptics a few years ago, but the major turnaround here now has me believing that there are still gains to be had for shareholders moving forward.
